thread.title: Intellectual property rights are not monopolies
thread.title_full: Intellectual property rights are not monopolies - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Intellectual property rights are not monopolies
text:
President Obama meets with agriculture and business leaders on the Trans-Pacific Partnership in Washington last week. At right is Bob Stallman, president of the American Farm Bureau. (Pool photo by Martin H. Simon/European Pressphoto Agency) October 12 at 4:59 PM The Oct. 10 Economy & Business article “ Protections for drug firms in trade bill fuel fresh opposition ” inaccurately referred to “monopolies” in discussing the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). Intellectual property rights are not monopolies. Rather, they protect the inventor’s property by affording the right to exclude others from commercially exploiting that which the inventor created. Were it not for the inventor, the public would not have the benefit of that invention.
The Constitution expressly acknowledges that the quid pro quo of a limited exclusive right in exchange for disclosure of the invention is an effective means for promoting the progress of the useful arts (
